reviews.review_msg: You need to memorize Hanyu Pinyin and tone marks. That's all that matters in the class. The assignment instructions are unclear, and her grading system is also somewhat questionable. But you cannot complain about this since she wouldn't give you a clear answer even though you sent her an email. but overall, she's not the worst prof

Be ready to learn pinyin if you are in this class. Her tests require you to write in pinyin rather than actually characters. She also does not acknowledge different dialects and if you give a different pronunciation during the oral test you will not get marks for it.

Very nice and approachable for asking questions. Course builds a lot off of CHIN100.

I have no background with Chinese before I took CHIN100, and I really enjoyed both CHIN100 and 110. This course does take quite a bit of time for studying, repetition for learning characters is very important. There's weekly quizzes, make sure to study beforehand.
